content.title: Peritoneal Dialysis
content.summary: Home-based renal replacement therapy using the peritoneal membrane as a dialysis membrane for solute and fluid removal through dwell exchanges
key_points: Uses peritoneal membrane as natural dialysis membrane with dextrose-based dialysate
CAPD: Manual exchanges 4-5 times daily; APD: Cycler-assisted overnight exchanges
Advantages: Home-based, preserves residual kidney function longer, no vascular access needed
Peritonitis is major complication; diagnose with cloudy effluent and WBC >100/μL (>50% PMNs)
PD catheter placed surgically or percutaneously; 2-week break-in period before use
Adequacy measured by weekly Kt/V urea ≥1.7 (including residual function)
Better for patients with preserved residual function, limited vascular access, or preference for independence
content.statement: Peritoneal dialysis is a home-based renal replacement therapy using the peritoneal membrane for solute and fluid exchange, offering lifestyle flexibility and preservation of residual kidney function.

explanation.intuition: In peritoneal dialysis, the peritoneum (membrane lining the abdominal cavity) acts as the dialysis filter. Dialysate fluid is instilled into the abdomen, wastes diffuse from blood vessels in the peritoneum into the fluid, and excess water is drawn out by osmotic pull of dextrose. After dwelling, the fluid is drained and replaced.
explanation.key_insight: PD offers comparable survival to HD in the first 2-3 years (especially with residual kidney function) while providing lifestyle advantages. However, technique survival is limited by peritonitis episodes and progressive membrane failure. Patient selection and training are critical to success.
explanation.technical_details: Solute clearance occurs by diffusion across the peritoneal membrane (blood vessels → dialysate). Water removal (ultrafiltration) is driven by osmotic gradient from dextrose (1.5%, 2.5%, 4.25% solutions) or icodextrin (glucose polymer for long dwells). Transport characteristics vary by patient (high/fast transporters have better clearance but less ultrafiltration; low/slow transporters vice versa) - assessed by peritoneal equilibration test (PET).

definitions_glossary.peritoneal_dialysis: Dialysis using peritoneal membrane as semipermeable dialyzing surface
definitions_glossary.capd: Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis; manual exchanges 4-5 times daily
definitions_glossary.apd: Automated peritoneal dialysis; cycler-assisted overnight exchanges
definitions_glossary.dwell_time: Time dialysate remains in peritoneal cavity before drainage
definitions_glossary.ultrafiltration: Fluid removal by osmotic gradient (dextrose) across peritoneum
definitions_glossary.pet: Peritoneal equilibration test; assesses membrane transport characteristics
definitions_glossary.high_transporter: Rapid solute equilibration but reduced ultrafiltration capacity
definitions_glossary.low_transporter: Slow solute equilibration but better ultrafiltration capacity
definitions_glossary.icodextrin: Glucose polymer dialysate for prolonged ultrafiltration in long dwells
definitions_glossary.peritonitis: Peritoneal infection; diagnosed by cloudy effluent, abdominal pain, WBC >100/μL
definitions_glossary.exit_site_infection: Infection at catheter exit site; can progress to tunnel infection
definitions_glossary.encapsulating_peritoneal_sclerosis: Rare, serious complication of long-term PD causing bowel encasement

pathophysiology.mechanism: Dialysis using peritoneal membrane vasculature for diffusive and osmotic exchange between blood and dialysate

transport_mechanisms.diffusion: Solute movement from blood across peritoneal membrane to dialysate
transport_mechanisms.osmotic_ultrafiltration: Water removal driven by osmotic gradient (dextrose concentration)

indications: ESRD with patient preference for home dialysis
Preserved residual kidney function (RKF enhanced preservation with PD)

adequacy_assessment.kt_v_urea: Weekly Kt/V ≥1.7 (total = PD + residual kidney function)
adequacy_assessment.clinical_assessment: Symptom control, nutrition, quality of life

capd.description: 4-5 manual exchanges daily; continuous dialysis with no machine
capd.typical_prescription: 2-2.5 L exchanges, 4-6 hour daytime dwells, overnight long dwell

apd.description: Cycler performs overnight exchanges while patient sleeps
apd.typical_prescription: 8-10 hours overnight with 10-15 L total, ± daytime exchange

modalities.hybrid_regimens: APD with wet day (leave dialysate in during day) or CCPD

dialysate_solutions.icodextrin: 7.5% glucose polymer for long dwells; sustained UF without glucose absorption
dialysate_solutions.amino_acid_based: Alternative to dextrose for malnourished patients

catheter_management.placement: Surgical or percutaneous; break-in period 2 weeks before full use
catheter_management.care: Exit site care, immobilization, monitoring for infection

peritonitis.diagnosis: Cloudy effluent + WBC >100/μL (>50% PMNs) + abdominal pain
peritonitis.treatment: IP antibiotics (vancomycin + aminoglycoside or cephalosporin); catheter removal if refractory
peritonitis.prevention: Sterile technique training, prophylactic mupirocin at exit site

complication_management.exit_site_infection: Topical and oral antibiotics; may need catheter replacement
complication_management.hernia: Common due to increased intra-abdominal pressure; surgical repair
complication_management.membrane_failure: Declining UF capacity over years; may need to transition to HD

skos.definition: Home-based renal replacement therapy using peritoneal membrane for solute and fluid exchange through dwell-and-drain cycles

subcodes: Z49.32 - Encounter for adequacy testing for peritoneal dialysis

learning_objectives: Explain principles of peritoneal dialysis (diffusion, osmotic ultrafiltration)
Assess PD adequacy using Kt/V and clinical parameters
Recognize and treat peritonitis according to ISPD guidelines
Select appropriate patients for PD vs HD
Understand membrane transport characteristics and PET interpretation
clinical_pearls: PD preserves residual kidney function longer than HD - important early in ESRD
Peritonitis diagnosis: cloudy bag + WBC >100 + abdominal pain; treat empirically, then adjust
High transporters clear well but ultrafiltrate poorly - use short dwells (APD) and icodextrin
Low transporters ultrafiltrate well but clear poorly - use long dwells (CAPD)
Exit site S. aureus colonization increases peritonitis risk - use prophylactic mupirocin
Avoid hypertonic dextrose (4.25%) long-term - accelerates membrane damage
Icodextrin is ideal for long dwells - sustained UF without glucose absorption
PD technique survival limited to ~5-10 years due to membrane failure and peritonitis
